reviewText: Like many others, I came across Ana Brett and Ravi Singh by surfing Amazon for new workout DVDs.  I had been looking for something gentler - yet still challenging and effective enough to be called fitness - to do in between my much more aggressive cardio/weight training workouts.  Amazon recommended them, and I was impressed by the loyal fan following that the DVDs had.  I decided to give one a try, and as I was still worried that it would be a little too New Age-y and "out there" for me, I decided to play it safe and chose "Ultimate Stretch Workout."  My reasoning was that even if I disliked the whole "enlightenment" thing, I would still get good use out of it as a stretching DVD.I am happy to say that not only did I greatly enjoy this DVD, but I will be purchasing others in the future.  This is something new for me...and I like it!I of coarse have done yoga before, and even own a few DVDs , which apparently are all Hatha yoga (never knew there were different types!), as opposed to this branch, which is kundalini.  Also, my previous DVDs are pretty athletically oriented, with the instructors' comments to "relax" and "let go" as spiritual as it gets.I initially kind of laughed when I began USW, as I was sooo unfamiliar with chanting foreign terminology.  I was even more caught off-guard by how much movement is in this yoga form.  Wheras my other yoga DVDs took me from static pose to static pose, this DVD had me twisting my waist and rocking (though of coarse there are still static poses here also). But I kept an open mind, and by the end of the hour-long DVD, I not only felt great physically, but great mentally, like I could take on anything and nothing could get in my way.  And without caffeine!This DVD is wonderful because it is both a physical fitness DVD and a mind fitness DVD.  It reminds you that you are a spiritual being, and this program places emphasis on not only letting your stress melt away, but opening yourself to become better, more purposeful and having nerves of steel.  At the end of this DVD, I feel a unique calm, while also ready to take on some formidable task, if that makes any sense at all!  :-)I also enjoy the physical aspect of this stretching because the intensity level varies throughout the program.  One minute you're moving a good deal and heating your body up, the next you're breathing deeply and calmly and could easily fall into sleep.  You also hold poses while doing the Breath of Fire, which makes the poses a little more difficult.  (I am still working on holding the Wheel position - basically a backbend - while doing Breath of Fire. Tough!)Though I now love Ana & Ravi, I will not stop worshipping at the temple of The Firm  during this lifetime!  I like to keep my body sculpted in a way that only harder cardio and resistance training can do. And hey, sometimes I just like hopping around , swinging weights until I drop.But I do plan on complementing my cardio-strength workouts with more of these wonderful DVDs.Sat Nam!  ;-)
summary: Stretch Your Body AND Your Mind..!
Title: N/A

reviewText: Unlike some of the other videos in this series, Ultimate Stretch focuses on just that--stretching. With two 30 min sets, the first focusing on the arms, the second on the legs, ending with a prolonged meditation. For beginners, there is also the option to add on a breath primer in the beginning. This video really helps to loosen up your muscles and to get your mind in tune with your body. It also includes an exercise in the beginning meant to help you build your nerves and stay calm under stress.  As other's have mentioned, the music is beautiful, and you end the video on a very positive, spiritual note.In another vein, my mother had a mastectomy two years ago and still suffers some effects of chemo, as well as suffering some mild flare-ups of lupus on occasion. Her muscles are often very tight and cause her pain, especially in her back and feet. This video really seems to help her stay nimble. So for that reason alone, five stars.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I bought this early in my discovery of Ravi and Ana, but for some reason put it away after doing in twice in favor of their newest workouts. However, since moving to another state this summer, I have rediscovered these older workouts and now will do nothing but! I like Ultimate Stretch because, as the name states, you get a fabulous stretch throughout your entire body. This is also one of the few workouts that gets my hamstrings burning in a nice way. It also starts out deceptively simple, but by the time I'm done, I'm sweating from bridge, cobra and stretch poses. I love the plain background and calm manner of these two yogic gurus. I am finding I prefer the simpler, older Raviana workouts. Highly recommended!
Title: N/A

reviewText: I have had Ultimate Stretch Workout for a few years now and continue to use it regularly. There are lots of forward bending poses (seated and standing), which I find both invigorating and very relaxing. However, people who don't enjoy hamstring stretches might not feel the same way I do!My other 'most used' Kundalini DVDs are:*Yoga Beauty Body (IMO the perfect yoga practice)*Dance the Chakras*Lose Weight & Feel Great*Total Tune-up (one of Ana's first DVDs - the music's not great but I love the yoga sets)*AM-PM Yoga (awesome AM set)*Yoga Quick Fixes (I actually prefer Dr Yoga House Call, but I love the mini sets in Quick Fixes).
summary: One of my most used Ana and Ravi DVDs

I learned alot about breathing and meditating with this dvd. the instructions are very clear and easy to follow. reviewText: The worst part, besides the barely anything routine, are the voice overs. She's breathy and infantile, a sort of bad stereotype of porno Barbie. He's creepy. I can hear the leer in his voice! Perhaps my Ashtanga background lends me to appreciate a more matter of fact, less soap opera / porn delivery, but... just sayin'.

Title: N/A

reviewText: I'm very new to yoga. Execpt for a few classes in high school (which was about 4 years ago), I have never even tried yoga. I'm also extremely inflexible. I bought this DVD mostly because I'm overweight and hate any aerobics or cardio and I really hate anything that involves going to a weight room or gym. A friend suggested I try yoga, so I bought this and I must say, I love it! This is the first workout video I've bought (and I have a lot!) that I don't think I can live without. Even though I'm not flexible, I can still do most of the poses (or at least a modified pose). There are a few I can't do, like the wheel and the crow pose, but the for the most part I don't feel like I'm so inadequate. I also love the breathing and the meditation. When I finish the workout, I feel so energized (which is why I never recommend doing this DVD right before bed). I already feel more flexible and my body has a very light soreness, but it doesn't interfere in my everyday life light the soreness you get from cardio does. I know that even when I get good at this workout, it will still present a challenge. This is a great DVD for beginning and advanced students and I recommend to anyone who wants a good workout in their own living room. I can't wait to get Ravi and Ana's entire DVD selection!

I crave kundalini yoga so much and all of their DVD's are just perfect!!!This one is one of my favorites along with the warrior workout. This DVD makes me feel happy, stable, less irritated, flexible, calm, and healthier... I couldn't ask for more. Even my husband mentioned yesterday that lately I'm in such a good mood!!! Wow that was a great compliment as I can get very edgy with my PMS. Even my PMS has improved with these workouts and meditations!!!I come from a hatha/power yoga background and after doing these DVD's I'm hooked into Kundalini with Ana & Ravi. I definitely feel better results mentally and physically from these DVD's than any other yoga DVD.The DVD is just awesome, perfect music, perfect workout, and great Mantra meditation at the end!!! reviewText: I bought this on sale from Amazon along with these authors' Fat Free Yoga and Kundalini Yoga for Beginners & Beyond. In a time when we're all counting our pennies, this has been, when I think about it, one of the best purchases of my life. All of these DVD's work on so many levels. Yoga helps you to be present and Kundalini Yoga is the best type of yoga I've found. It is very engaging and active and combines movement exercises along with poses and breathing with almost everything. If you haven't done this type of yoga, there are no words to describe how alive you feel when you really breathe. It's like waking up from a sluggish dream of walking through wet cement and discovering that you can fly in real life. This DVD starts with exercises which open up the solar plexus. As Ana & Ravi explain, this area has to be opened before the rest of our body can release. There is a great stretching sequence involving exercises you won't find anywhere else and a beautiful meditation at the end. This DVD is a gem!

reviewText: After too long skipping out on KY in favor of other types of exercise, I found myself feeling strung out. physically depleted and, worst of all, with a very short fuse. I started back up with my set of Ana/Ravi workouts and quickly find my mood evening out again, feel my hips and lower back releasing all the stress I didn't realize I was holding on to, sleeping easier and better, and looking forward to my yoga all day long. This particular DVD is a favorite that has been really helpful in regaining my emotional equilibrium. I don't know if it's the workouts themselves, or returning to a more regular yoga practice, but when I feel like I need a break, Ana/Ravi KY workouts are almost always exactly what I need.I really love these workouts, so I was intrigued to see why some people seem to really dislike them- some people mention feeling annoyed, and I wanted to say that when I'm doing a KY workout, there's often a point at which I get irritable and annoyed, but if I work through it, it's like massaging out a know in a muscle, and not only do I feel better, but the next time I do the same workout, I don't get annoyed in that same place. Through a KY practice I've learned to be more mindful about identifying why I am feeling irritable, angry, annoyed, bored and tense. But as with any practice, if you don't keep it up, even mental and emotional muscles (if you can call them that) lose their fitness and, like me, you can get out of touch with yourself. If you're on the fence about the Ana/Ravi DVDs based on the negative comments, I encourage you to give them a hot anyway (you can always return them and there are plenty of Ravi/Ana fans who will be your practically new DVD from you) and, if you don't love them at first, try them again, and maybe again- sometimes it takes time to see benefits from a new program.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Stretching was something I always resisted. Cardio and strength training came first, but I knew I needed to start some stretching before I lost my flexibility all together. This ws just what I needed! I have found other yoga workouts far too boring: just holding poses while you listen to an anatomy lesson! Ana & Ravi's style of yoga is active and gets into deep places right away. You don't have to wait months like you would for the static types of poses to finally kick in. From the very first time I did this I felt the anxiety I always carry around my midriff dissipate as well as an immediate release in my hips, lower back, and hamstrings. I also felt completely energized and I now know what everyone is talking  about when they discuss that "yoga glow." Next payday, I am going to order their new Kundalini Yoga Cardio, Stretch, & Strengthen and Yoga for Beginners & Beyond: Stretch, Strengthen, Be Stress Free!

The reason I need to work on stretching is that I often skip that part of a workout because it find it boring, but with Ana & Ravi's DVD's, it's never boring! Their style is very dynamic but the end result is pure bliss. I can't speak highly enough about this one and all of their DVD's!
Title: N/A

reviewText: Kundalini yoga ultimate stretch workout with Ana and Ravi.Another great Kundalini yoga dvd by Ana and Ravi. I have a few of their DVD classes now and love all of them. I also have Maya Fiennes, Gurumkh's and Gurutej's and also Erin Kalmer's. I have been practicing Kundalini yoga for approx one year now and prior to that I had practiced Hatha yoga for approx one year. My main practice is Kundalini as I knew it was what I had been looking for after working with my first DVD which was Maya Fiennes Detox and Destress.This DVD begins with the Tune in via mantra and then goes into some wonderful warm ups, I really enjoy the warm up sections as it prepares my mind and body for the class. The main part of the class comes next and the stretches are really good, I enjoy what I can achieve within my own limitations and cannot flex as much as Ana, but that is fine as Kundalini Yoga is about doing 'your' best, so whatever you can do is great. There is a period of savasana (corpse pose, relaxation on your back) and then a lovely meditation, really lovely. Then finally class ends with the tune out via mantra.I am very peaceful at the end of the session, I am also energised and happy and feel stretched. Beautiful.Ana and Ravi encourage throughout, the guidance is clear and I find it easy to follow and Ana demonstrates beautifully.Sat Nam x
summary: This works so well for me!  Brilliant!
Title: N/A

reviewText: I was disappointed with this DVD considering the many positive comments.  As with most Yoga workouts, I know that there is going to be quite some focus on the "spiritual" aspect of Yoga.  However, it was not too much of a big deal with Ultimate Stretch...there was a little of the "ohm" thing at the beginning of the workout, but I appreciated that the rest of the workout, for the most part, focused on the moves themselves. Both Ravi and Ana merely pointed out the physical benefits of each pose and didn't dwell on any "spiritual" benefits.  There were a couple moves for the kegel muscles (sat kriya I think??), etc that "required" repeating some mantras, but I just fast-forwarded those.One of my complaints is with the breath of fire and the lack of explanation as to what exactly this was...I sort of figured it out eventually, but it would have been nice to be given specific instructions.  Also, the modified poses were only shown for a couple moves and the "box" showing the modifications was not kept up for long, so one didn't get much time to ensure you were doing the pose correctly...there were also others like the plow and backbend (ashtanga dropback) where the modification wasn't shown at all.I was disappointed with the workout mainly because while there were many poses focusing on stretching the lower body (hips, back, legs, abs), I recall maybe only one that focused on the upper body (chest, shoulders, neck, arms), so the title "ultimate stretch" is misleading.The last two (2) levels were much too drawn out (relaxation and meditation) and I simply turned off the DVD after a couple minutes of the relaxation session.  I must admit though, that from what I was able to do, I actually felt the burn in my legs days later, and I appreciated the length of time taken to do each move...wasn't rushed at all.All in all, not what I was expecting, so I've ordered three of Rodney Yee's workouts - Yoga for Beginners, Power Yoga-Flexibility and Power Yoga-Total Body Workout, in my continued quest to find a Yoga workout that meets all my requirements, namely to increase flexibility and strength in a format that's "mantra-free" and progressive (easy to challenging), and also which will teach correct form and breathing.
summary: IT'S OK BUT DOESN'T GIVE A FULL BODY STRETCH
Title: N/A

reviewText: In a nutshell, you have a very slender woman whose spine is as flexible as overcooked spahgetti doing some very intense stretching for an hour, in her underwear.One of the exercises had her squatting down, looping her arms behind her legs, grabbing her ankles and breathing in and out like she was giving birth to twins.  I guess that's some kind of mystical thing but I since I couldn't do it, I just sat down on the couch and laughed at it.  I sat on the couch for most of it.If I were twenty, had her figure and her degree of flexibility, I would probably rate this production 4 or 5 stars; it is that good.However, if you have trouble tying your shoes, this DVD ain't for you! My recommendation for us older folks is Pilates Complete for Inflexible People with Maggie Rhoades. It's a whole lot easier than this.

reviewText: Ultimate Stretch is a must have for anyone declaring peace and centering.the matrix set options are perfect as you can skip certain exercises or do them in different order.  i reccomend all in order, although i usually skip the easing stress exercise.  the music is nice i imagine a village full of yogas doin kundalini.  the mantras are my favorite... it's vibrating and really helps you to engage in the exercise before and after leaving you with peace all day.  Ravi's voice and dialogue with Ana makes you feel like they are in the room with you walking around making sure everyone is on point.  love their dvds.i've included this as my pre/post week workout considering all of my muscles need kundalini in it's most relaxing form.  my pre/post workout is a juggle between the Ultimate Stretch and Kundalini for Beginners and Beyond.somehow someway please try to include some form of Kundalini in your life either weekly or monthly at the least.  my next purchase is going to be Kundalini meditations believing that this form of yoga is the best way for me to achieve it!

reviewText: I love to do Ultimate Stretch in the evening - I am putty afterwards!I used to have trouble sleeping, but it seems like insomnia is becoming a rarity for me now. The entire routine is about 55 minutes long but can be broken up into shorter segments. What a joy this program has been! From head to toe, I am worked out, relaxed and stretched out when finished. Very fluid moves, very easy to follow, and great alignment tips to "drop" you into the pose, as well as inspirations to start or end the day. I could go on and on about all of the Ravi Singh & Ana DVD's I have tried, but I really recommend you try one for yourself - - soon!

reviewText: I love love love Ana & Ravi's DVDs. I own six so far, and most of them are a balance of a great workout and sort of a refreshing/relaxing energy boost. I thought this stretching DVD would be cake, so I put it in at night for a wind-down workout. Much to my surprise, there were some moves that were more advanced and more difficult than in the other DVDs I'd done before. Not that the workout isn't great-- just that I read "Stretch Workout" and imagined "easy workout."What makes their DVDs so extraordinary is a combination of the pacing, the demonstrations/explanations, and the affirmations they share throughout. I find myself using the mantras they've taught me throughout my day, alleviating stress with the breathing techniques they use in the video, and reminding myself to "do my best and be so blessed." Theirs are by far the best workout videos I have ever used, and I would strongly recommend them to anyone-- regardless of yoga experience or fitness level.
summary: Not as easy as I'd imagined!
Title: N/A

reviewText: Stretching has never been one of my strong points, or favorite things to do, but this great DVD made stretching very enjoyable for me. This warm-ups on this open up the midriff area and work on loosening up the spine. Then you do a great standing stretch sequence. My doctor had talked to me about increasing the oxygen saturation in my blood and he couldn't believe the improvment after I had been doing this workout. He assures me that because of this type of yoga breathing I will live longer and look younger(the fact that doctors are now talking like that means we've come a long way!). This DVD also has ab exercises and things which work the upper body. I can't quite get into Wheel Pose but they give a good modification. Overall, this is one of the best DVD's I've tried.
summary: Just My Speed, Great Fun Stretch

reviewText: I usually skip stretching because it bores me to death. I recently bought some of the Ana Brett & Ravi Singh DVD's because I'm turning 50 this year and I want to get in the best shape of my life. I decided stretching should be part of my routine as well. The rest of their DVD's I've tried were so much fun, I hoped that they had made stretching fun and I was right. These are not your same old workout/yoga stretches. reviewText: Unless you're a skinny 18-year old and a contortionist, don't waste your money  on this video.  I bought this a while back -- around 2011 -- and today I played it again and tried to do some of the moves.  Most of them are impossible for the average person.  If you want to get stretched, start with something more akin to what they teach in normal aerobics classes during the warm-up and cool-down.  I also did not care for the meditation and music on this video, as I don't see what that has to do with fitness.  I also don't like videos where the instructors are half-naked.  The girl could have put on some nice yoga pants and a top that covered her middle.  I am not a prude -- I just don't like to see bare skin.  However, I could have ignored that part had the exercises/stretches been do-able.

reviewText: What Can I say that hasn't been said in 52 reviews? This video is a very well put together class. Lasting 60 minutes total, it is divided into 5 chapters at the menu.First, Ana takes you into deep guided breathing, with the voice off of Ravi Singh. The breathing technique is designed to "let nothing get on your nerves"... their words.Next chapter finds you singing a Mantra for the session.Next, comes the warming up and lenghtening exercises, well put together and useful for starting to get things going.Then, the meaty part. A series of Asanas designed to lenghten the body and increase flexibility. What I like about this video is that, even though you don't get to do a ton of pistures, Ana holds them a little longer that your average video. Thus, you do forward bends, cobra, Bat pose, and a few others while breathing normally or doing Breath of Fire.Finally relaxation and mantra singing come.In total, a 60 minute lesson. If you skip the beggining breathing and mantra you get 50 minutes.About production, I tend to get more into a Yoga video if I like the sorroundings it was taped in...In this case the video is done with 2 or 3 cameras, in a closed enviroment, having Ana on top of some carpeted box, with clouds and sky wallpaper all around. Not too inspiring.I tried to get this video from Amazon twice, never arrived, they are really having problems with International deliveries. Bought it from 'that' auction site directly from Ana and Ravi, and don't regret it. Recommended
Title: N/A

reviewText: This has not only helped me to touch my toes (which I can now do COMFORTABLY!) But it's fun too, like all their DVDs, and I really appreciate them making us enjoy the workouts. I think the secret to why this works so well to improve flexibility lies in its use of the breath with movement. The breath is making the mind relax at the same time the muscles kind of melt and relax into lengthening. Ravi's soothing voice also makes my muscles want to let go, and Ana is an awesome inspiration to watch. Just a beautiful and perfect yoga stretch program. Highly recommended!

Title: N/A

reviewText: Okay so I know stretching is an important part of fitness, but it's what I tend to skip the most.  With this DVD, I actually look forward to stretching.What I love about this DVD:**the clean white set.  Ravi and Ana's 2009/2010 workouts are filmed with a very fake looking outdoors set that's distracting, so the clean white set of their earlier workouts is a plus.**Ravi's soothing voice.**the combination of breath work and stretching.  I know that breathing into a stretch helps you stretch further, but it wasn't until I started doing this DVD that I really made the connection.**the emphasis on stretching.  My hamstrings are very tight because of all the cardio I do and doing this workout really makes them feel good.**the short, but effective mediations.  I like that Ravi explains the meaning of the final "wahay guru" meditation so I don't feel like I'm just saying words that have no meaning.  It also helps to have the words appear on the screen so you can remember what to say.One very minor point is that Ravi doesn't mirror cue, so it could be confusing for some folks.Maybe I'm more flexible than I give myself credit because I think this DVD is suitable for all fitness levels.  I know some of the other reviewers thought it too advanced for beginners.I highly recommend this workout to anyone wanting a nice yoga and stretching workout.
summary: Perfect blend of stretching and yoga
Title: N/A

reviewText: I was expecting an hour of stretching, but that's not what this video offers. It offers approximately half an hour of stretching, the other half consists of vocal cord stretching with chanting and singing. The stretches, the little that there is of them, are good and work the body. The video is well done, the workout model is lovely, and the commentator's voice is soothing and calm. The poses are easy, although challenging because one has to hold them for extended periods of time. I was disappointed that this wasn't a traditional yogaish type of exercise. The singing and chanting mumbo jumbo was a little far fetched for me-but others may enjoy it. I prefer the Shiva Ria and Deb Dobbin videos, which offer a more comprehensive practice. I would have been more comfortable with this video if it offered an hour of exercise like it states. The ~half an hour of exercise was not sufficient for me.
summary: I don't consider chanting ultimate stretch
Title: N/A

reviewText: I believe this is the #1 Kundalini DVD out there.  I discovered this Kundalini Yoga Series by Ana Brett and Ravi Singh on Amazon about 2 years ago and it is incredible.  I have been doing casual yoga of various sorts here and there via DVD and at the (Hatha, Kripalu, etc.) over the years but this series by Ana Brett and Ravi Singh fundamentally changed my approach to wellness, fitness,  personal growth and outlook on life.  I was incredibly stiff and out of shape before finding these DVDs.  I was totally new to Kundalini Yoga and, frankly, a but skeptical about it since it has some "unusual" moves and poses and chanting compared to other forms of exercise and Yoga I have done at the gym and via DVDs.  Now I see the power of Kundalini via Ana and Ravi "technology" that integrates physicality, mindfulness, and spirit.  It is not easy at first - but that is the point.  You do what you can, dot judge yourself and you reap massive benefits.  I progressed quite rapidly from things I felt were impossible but worth trying to not so hard to challenging to "not hard any more".  I feel GREAT every single time I complete a DVD - -my mood, my body, my creativity, my stress, my mind clarity, my stamina, etc.  Its truly amazing.  The key to reaping these benefits is to not get caught up in saying "this is weird" but to say "just try it and see how you feel".  Incredibly fit and wise people did this type of yoga and meditation hundreds and thousands of years ago as a regular regime but Western society has somehow made it non-traditional and inaccessible.  Many other types of Yoga focus too much on the body and physicality and don't see the mind, body, spirit interconnection like Ravi and Ana.  Ravi and Ana make it so accessible - combining direction on how to do the poses and breathwork and sounds (mantras) that vibrate your body to heal it, strengthen it and give new clarity.  Ana demonstrates the poses (don't be intimidated by how easy she makes things look - just do your best is what I found) and Ravi and Ana explain the physiological basis of how each pose affects your glands, nervous system, muscular system. Brain and energy and spirit.  Ravi has amazing poetry sprinkled in to make it just a beautiful relaxing experience (even though its quite physical!).  The production is very professionally done -- different angles, alternatives if you have certain issues or challenges, music editing, pacing, etc.  I totally recommend any of Ana Brett and Ravi Singh's DVD's to anyone whether you do Yoga already or not.  It can truly take your fitness to another level along with your outlook on life.  Good luck!Kundalini Yoga Meditation for Beginners & Beyond
summary: The Best DVD Yoga Series I have found -- I am SOO much more flexible

They suggested that I do this DVD, so I included it in my yoga workous 2-3x a week. In about 6 weeks my sciatica is under control! This whole workout is just under an hour and the time flies! Very concise. Very professional. Very uplifting. Everything you want in a yoga session and more!

reviewText: I had just accepted the fact that I was probably going to be less flexible as the years ticked off. I'm 32 and I had no expectations when I started doing this about twice per week in rotation with other Ana & Ravi DVD's. While I was doing my yoga this morning I had the revelation that I could go down further over my legs than I've been able to in a long time. Also, I used to have a lot of discomfort between my shoulderblades and I realize that that's gone away as well. Ana & Ravi are genius at being able to bring a person along without ever feeling like you're being pushed. You never feel guilty about not being able to be a perfect yoga person. That's why I keep going back to their DVD's again and again.

reviewText: Ana and Ravi are the best  yoga teachers out there because in their DVD's they present what yoga is really meant to be about. Nothing about their work is typical. They go beneath the service and get to the heart of the matter. That holds true for the concept of stretching.  This inspiring DVD starts (as they explain it) by opening the solar plexus so that the whole body can release. Then they offer some amazing stretching and more. This is a well-rounded workout. If you are a yoga or fitness person you will find many new things to inspire your workouts. If you are a person who is exercise-resistant, then you can rest assured that you are in really good hands with Ana & Ravi and that their workouts work faster than anything!

reviewText: I purchased this DVD, because my inner thighs lack flexibility.  The summary and reviews indicated that this DVD would help that.  Well, if your legs already bend like wet noodles, then this DVD is for you.  If, like me, the butterfly means your legs are flying in the air and not on the ground, then you will not like this DVD.To put this in perspective: I am not a yoga fan at all.  I thought this DVD would focus more on stretches and maybe some meditation to increase your flexibility.  It did that, but not in a likeable way.Part I: Some type of chants about something.  I think it was to Guru or somebody.Part II: Some stretches, which I liked.  The one most helpful to me was the sitting on the floor with the legs cross and swirling the abdomenPart III: The stretches that I could not do.  The butterfly stretch with you laying across the legs just had me sitting there.  I did the frog stretch (the modified version), but didn't like itPart IV: Some more chanting to the Guru personMy review of the DVD:It was boring beyond belief.  I almost fell asleep in the middle of it a number of times.  One reason it was so boring, it is just one lady on a white backdrop doing stretches.  Another reason why it was so boring is that you hold the stretches for so long that it is just ridiculous.True yoga and feel the earth people who think the world revolves in 10 minute intervals will like this DVD.  People who like the world to move at a regular steady pace will not like this video.Also, if you are not flexible, the flexibility of this instructor will be intimidating to you.  They should have at least included an inflexible person for the modifications.Update: I returned the DVD.  I found my Stretching for Dummies Book which more helpful to my goal of increased flexibility.Update #2: Any yoga dvd or stretches would achieve the same results as this DVD.

reviewText: I have recently begun to do all yoga as fitness. I had been doing a pretty high-impact workout routine 6 days a week. Now I do yoga instead for 6 days. I do mostly Ana Brett & Ravi Singh yoga workouts. I really like their type of yoga because it feels very aerobic. It is a mild form of cardio that feels much healthier to my body then all that hard stepping up and down and running that I had been doing  I have been amazed to see I have finally started losing weight and actually seeing some muscles in my arms legs, back and stomach - all former problem areas.The only other thing I do, which is something I have always done,  is walking at a fairly good pace. I live in the city and take about 2 twenty minute brisk walks to the subway and back and then walking to do shopping.I am beginning to think this yoga is all I need.

reviewText: This dynamic duo epitomizes the elegance of Kundalini yoga.  They are clearly experts in the art form of Kundalini Yoga to shape and define the body and mind.  They clearly explain each pose or exercise as it relates to its benefits for both the mind and body.  They emphasize internal toning (organs) with as much emphasis as improving the body's exterior.  From their perspective the two are intertwined together.  After a Ravi and Anna workout, I feel a significant boost in the mind, body and spirit.  I never feel tired, but rather toned, relaxed and calm.  In no time you will find yourself mastering the positions and postures.  They provide plenty of alternatives for those who are simply unable to achieve some of the full postures yet.  But have no fear, with practice and patience, you will achieve them -- no push from either of them.  The beauty of this ancient art form is fully revealed by these two.  As an added plus, you will notice an improvement in your flexibility, energy level and definately body tone.  You can literally reshape your body.  Give it a shot!

reviewText: My Back, Waist, Love Handle, Hamstring muscles are still aching since yesterday's workout. This yoga is very dynamic and truly stretches you... Yet I've gone too far with the stretching that I'm sore today, but I highly recommend it for those who have not worked their back muscles for a while.This workout will give you:-Whole Back Stretch (You'll be moving in some asanas and stagnant in others)-Hamstring Stretch (Moving during this stretch)-Waist and Ab Stretch (You'll be moving throughout this stretch)-Inner thigh Stretch (an area I tend to forget)-Arms & Shoulder Stretch-Quadriceps and Outer Thigh Stretch (Breathing rapidly while holding the asana making your thighs burn!)****Used once/twice a month this workout will help your muscles relax and relieve tension buildup.
summary: A true Stretch for the Back, Waist and Hamstring!

reviewText: I am no yoga guru, mainly a runner by habit.  I have tried other yoga dvds but have always felt somewhat disappointed - too complicated and hence dont get the benefit, or way too simple that I am bored within 10 minutes and I am already zooming ahead to see if it gets any better.  This is my first dvd of Ravi and Ana's selection and was inspired to buy it from the positive reviews and that I have pretty tight muslces especially my back.  I was neither bored nor put off by the complicated poses - I may not have had the energy to stay the course on some of the poses, but I attempted them and stayed as long I could given my current fitness level.  This dvd is great for all levels, and you will be inspired to push yourself a little bit more.  After trying it for the first time this morning, it is 12 hours on and my energy is at a good place, (although I have started on a healthier eating plan replaced with all whole wheat food, minumum sodium, minimum processed food) .. so with this workout this is all benefiting all the other steps that  I am taking in my life [2007 resolution was to live a much reduced stressed life!! and the Universe has send me to this workout as part of my achieving my goal].  Like many people, I will no doubt buy more of their workouts - it is one of the best form of yoga for beginners and for those yogis who want something new.  I love the breathing techniques and the break with meditation pauses, but this got a four star since I felt there could have been a little more explanation of the benefits of eacg pose/stretch.  Otherwise, it was easy to follow.Day2: I surprised myself and ended up this morning repeating this exercise .. was not bored as I thought I would be, pushed myself to stay a little longer on some poses.  My blood pressure was even lower after one hour of this exercise - much better than after a four mile run.  I am beginning to see why these instructors are popular.  Finally, I can almost say that I may have found a form of yoga that I connect with both on a spiritual and physical level.  A good workout with modified forms for those who need it (like me, for now).  Hopefully their other dvds are as good as everyone say they are.November 2007: I have all of Ravi and Ana's dvds and this remains a firm favorite,  I am glowing and people have noticed how much less stressed I am; just plain happy.  The physical benefits can be felt within days, and my spiritual growth has flourished.  Ravi and Ana are by far the best teachers in terms of dvds compared to other famous kundaline teachers, other yoga teacheers in fact.  However, I would love to see some book publications too to provide more depth of kundalini yoga teachings.  Or how about a dvd for prenatal/postnatal and throw one in for meditations alone!  Keeps the teachings coming -I am loving it.  Thank you so much Ravi and Ana, Sut Nam

reviewText: This review will have a two-part format. In the first part, I'll describe the contents of the DVD as well as my thoughts on them. In the second part, I'll say some more general things about Ana and Ravi and kundalini yoga. It seems the negative reviews of their DVDs come mainly from people who didn't know what to expect when ordering kundalini yoga DVDs -- because they ARE a little bit different from what you're used to, if you've only practiced hatha yoga in the past. I am unabashedly an Ana and Ravi fan, but hopefully my evaluation will help you make the correct decision for yourself, even if your opinion happens not to be the same as mine.----------Part I----------Like many of Ana and Ravi's DVDs, the Ultimate Stretch Workout has the matrix menu. This feature appears to have been added in later, as this looks like it is one of Ana's and Ravi's earlier DVDs. All exercises in this DVD are done equally on both sides of the body.Breath Primer (4:28): This was recorded later than the rest of the DVD (as evidenced by the set, for those of you familiar with Ana's and Ravi's other work).  At any rate, it provides instruction in long deep breathing, in a panting breath that serves as an entry point to breath of fire, and in breath of fire, itself.  I highly recommend that beginners watch this segment, but it's also a good reminder to more advanced practitioners of kundalini yoga.  It might not play if you select "play DVD" from the menu, but is available either via the matrix menu or the chapter menu.Tune In (2:40): This segment is similar/the same in many of Ana's and Ravi's DVDs; sit cross-legged, focus on your breathing, and chant "ong namo guru dev namo" three times.Anti-Stress Breathing Exercise (3:29): In this segment, you sit cross-legged with your hands in a mudra (hand position).  You breath in, in 10 breaths, while moving your hands up to your forehead in 10 movements.  You then exhale in one breath.Warm-Ups (3:27): This is a very short warm-up for one of these DVDs. It consists of only two exercises.*sitting cross-legged, grind your stomach in circles*still sitting cross-legged, hold your shins and flex your spine back and forthUltimate Stretch Set 1 (17:07): This set consists of the following exercises and is completely performed while standing, which is a little unusual for a kundalini yoga DVD (but is great if you're looking for a DVD with lots of standing exercises).*with your feet together, extend your arms overhead and hook your thumbs; inhale and lean back; exhale and lean forward, bending to the floor*with your palms together overhead, lean to one side, come back center, then lean to the other side*standing, bend your knees and extend your arms to the side; hold your hands out as if pressing against walls on both sides*with shoulder-width legs, touch toes on one foot with the opposite hand; alternate (this was also in the Navel Power DVD)*standing with one foot a few feet in front of the other, clasp your hands behind your back and lean forward over the front leg; extend your arms above your back*facing forward, with your legs wide, hook your big toes with your fingers and lean forward with your head up*a challenge for your coordination: standing, press your elbows back (inhale); tap your diaphragm with your fists (exhale); touch the floor (inhale); tap your sternum (exhale); some of the floor touching is performed to the right or left*chair pose variation with your hands around the backs of your ankles*with your feet together, leaning forward, hold under your toes; inhale and bring your head up; exhale and hold your ankles and pull your head downUltimate Stretch Set 2 (19:35): This set consists of the following exercises. If you're not looking, it's easy to miss the transition between the first and second stretching sets - not a problem if you're using the matrix menu, though.*crow or the down position of frog with breath of fire*butterfly*sit on one heel with the other leg extended; clasp your hands overhead; exhale down over the extended leg and inhale back up*plow*lie on your stomach, push up into cobra, come back down*in cobra, look to one side, come back to center, then look to the other side*bridge or wheel*stretch pose (with your palms under you for support, lift your head and heels off the ground six inches) with breath of fire*sat kriya (complicated to explain if you're not familiar; just look it up online for more information)Deep Relaxation (2:17): This is similar in many of Ravi's and Ana's DVDs. Lie on your back, slow your breathing, and listen.  Ana does at least some of the talking here.Mantra Meditation (5:52): The mantra segment on this one is one of my two favorites (the other favorite of mine is from the Dance the Chakras DVD).  It's singing along with Wah! and here are the words:Guru Guru Wahay GuruGuru Ram Das GuruI just really like the melody for this one.Closing Prayer (2:17): This is the same as in all of Ravi's and Ana's other DVDs and involves holding the breath while thinking various thoughts.  It ends with a long "sat nam."For those of you familiar with Ravi's and Ana's DVDs, this is a fairly old one with Ana demonstrating on a raised platform that's lighted from within and a fake clouds background. Mostly Ravi narrates, while Ana demonstrates the poses and movements. Ana does some voiceover work that appears to have been recorded later.  The camera moves some but it's not as distracting as in some of the newer (blonde Ana) DVDs, and you don't miss anything important. Occasionally, the camera picks up the edge of the set and you can see audio-visual equipment, but most of the time, there's a decent illusion of space. The music is not terribly noticeable most of the time.There is a fair amount of content that's repeated from Ana's and Ravi's Navel Power DVD.  It looks like the segments for this one were filmed at the same time and some exercises were spliced into both.  If you want a DVD with a lot of standing poses, this is a great one for that.  It has a nice mix of static stretches and active movements.  This DVD is pretty low on the breath of fire and heavy on the long deep breathing.I have about 2/3 of Ana's and Ravi's DVDs, and I think this one is solid. I think even beginners can use this one, as long as they follow some of the modifications (i.e., don't jump immediately into an attempt at wheel!). Ana and Ravi do offer some suggestions for modifications of many of the poses. I simply can't do wheel, for example, and I am not flexible enough for plow first thing in the morning. Finally, don't forget -- you don't have to keep up with Ana. Work at your own pace.I like the sets in this one; they provide a nice mix of upper and lower body stretches.  I feel like my legs (my problem area, when it comes to tightness) probably get the biggest benefit.----------Part II----------Now, on to a more general discussion of kundalini yoga in general, and Ana's and Ravi's DVDs in particular. (I intend to include a version of this in all my reviews of Ana's and Ravi's DVDs.)Most of the yoga that people are familiar with falls under the umbrella of hatha yoga. Perhaps you've done a series of static poses, or some vinyasa/flow yoga. Kundalini yoga is not exactly like either of these, although Ana's and Ravi's DVDs do incorporate elements of hatha yoga (e.g., this DVD has bow pose in it). However, kundalini yoga is also what I would consider to be a very active form of yoga, consisting of some repeated movements and a lot more work with the breath than you may be used to. It can be difficult to keep up with at first, but can be very rewarding if you stick with it. If you are bored of holding static poses all the time, or if you want a bit more movement but hate vinyasa (sorry, but I am not a fan of flow yoga), kundalini might really work well for you. And, as I said earlier, use the modifications Ana and Ravi discuss if you need to use them. Yes, Ana is fit (and this makes her an excellent demonstrator for the poses), but this is not a competition. Don't strain yourself, and don't try to keep up with her. Just try to improve a little bit every time!Kundalini yoga also involves a lot of meditation. Sometimes this is quiet and involves breathing either in a sitting position or lying down, occasionally with your hands in a mudra (hand position). Sometimes it involves chanting a mantra. This DVD contains a fair amount of mantra chanting - there's the chanting segment, as well as the opening and closing segments. Whenever there are mantras, Ana and Ravi tell you what they mean. If you are uncomfortable with mantras for religious reasons, check out Ana's and Ravi's website (can't post links in reviews but they're easy to find through Google) for alternatives and use the matrix menu or your DVD remote to skip the chant. (I happen to like the chants, but that's just me.)With respect to calorie-burning, this is probably not the sort of program that will make you shed a ton of weight. What this DVD is particularly good for is exactly what it says - stretching. But kundalini yoga works on your inner self as well as your outer self, and so some parts are a little less "active" than others. For my own part, I still do plenty of pretty intense cardio at other times of the day.Ana's outfits are a bit skimpy, but certainly nothing less than you would see at the beach. And the reason she dresses like she does is so that you can really see her performing the movements and asanas. That way you know exactly how to position yourself for maximum benefit. (Most of the time, kundalini yoga is done with the eyes closed, anyway.) There is not a lot in the way of initial instruction in this DVD. If you are familiar with Ana's and Ravi's work, you can jump right in. But if you are new to kundalini yoga, watch it first. Observe Ana, listen to the cues, make sure you understand. You'll be glad for the lack of excessive instruction later -- you don't want to be told on the 20th time you do a DVD how to do plow; you know it by this point!Some health claims are made in this DVD; take these with a grain of salt (there is a warning at the beginning that the claims come from "traditional" sources).  I do find that Ana and Ravi are quite accurate when it comes to muscular and skeletal issues. At any rate, certainly don't use yoga as a substitute for seeing the doctor. But doing a routine like this isn't likely to hurt you or make your health condition worse (as long as you PACE YOURSELF).If you are struggling with a pose, Ravi and Ana are very accessible and quite nice. They have contact information on their website (the URL is on the DVD case) and usually get back to you in a couple of days. They also have a monthly e-mail newsletter that I enjoy.

reviewText: Based on the results I've seen, I have found this to be an amazing, concise workout, which works deeply and powerfully, not only in terms of flexibility but also in freeing up your mind, emotions, and energy. Many workouts, I've found, try to force flexibility from the outside in. That approach of course causes a risk of injury over time. Ultimate Stretch Workout, and the Kundalini Yoga style featured in all of the Ravi Singh & Ana Brett DVD's, uses breath work in conjunction with poses and movement to organically delve deep and trigger breakthroughs on all levels. This is a dynamic, flowing, fun, experience which I can't get enough of. In addition to great physical yoga, the meditation at the end totally opened my heart!
Title: N/A

reviewText: I have no problem with an intermediate vinyasa class. Based on all the fantastic reviews, I had to purchase three of these DVDs.I'm frankly baffled by the degree of enthusiasm for them, and so I must be either missing something or too impatient. But this kind of physical-breath practice was far more frustrating than beneficial for me, and almost wonder if this kind of instruction is mandatory to have in person rather than DVD.First, unlike more typical asana instruction (Iyengar, Vinyasa, Ashtanga) the combination of breath and physical posture never once felt to me coherently linked, comfortable, flowing, or even potentially enhancing of well-being. No doubt some of it is practice and (again) patience, but usually when confronted with similar challenges in other yoga disciplines I have felt both a present challenge to my comfort, but also a deeper awareness of future or potential ease, gain, comfort, or well-being. Not for one moment I have felt them using this instruction.The degrees of difficulty are all over the map. Beginners could keep up with many of the sequences, but absolutely not a pose just minutes later (one example: the transition from Bridge pose to a full Upward Bow, which Ana holds doing breath of fire for an insanely long time). Ravi Singh's voice-over urges patience for beginners, but that is inadequate. This pose seems too advanced to simply appear when and as it does in this sequence. Other more frustrating moments include one of the movements, which require a quick transition from toe-tap, to solar plexus, to opposite toe-tap, to sternum, all coordinating the breath in specific ways and all happening much too fast for a first or second-timer to feel comfortable with the pace. It's a disincentive to try again.Most tellingly for me, the transitions in and out of the poses never feel right. Unlike other practices (esp Vinyasa and Ashtanga) where a deeper wisdom links one pose to what follows, I felt myself tight and uncomfortable in many of the transitions.I'm a lightweight Buddhist so am not at all offended by the chanting, nor do I feel it should be taken as inconsistent with other traditions. But it didn't feel to me at all energetically meaningful either. Apparently, no Hindu past lives for me....Finally, the production values can be just flat-out strange. In one of the DVDs, the stage includes a circle of small, round, crummy looking rugs, none of which is large enough for an entire body. And -- this is stupid I know -- on one of them (don't remember which) but I couldn't help wondering why the director couldn't have offered a washcloth for the bottom of Ana's feet. For the director of a product that's 95% visual, just seems like a no-brainer.For all the enthusiasm other reviewers have for this work, I desperately wanted these DVDs in my rotation. Again, it is almost certainly a simple mismatch between me and this practice. Can someone please shed some light about what I'm missing? Meantime, I'm going back to Iyengar/Vinyasa.

reviewText: The dvd is about an hour long, the breathing exercises and the mantras take about 20 minutes so you're getting about 40 minutes of actual postures.This is a great series for stretching out the lower back and legs especially. I definitely feel this one the next day. Some of the poses are quite challenging, plow pose was a difficult one for me to get into at first. She also does wheel pose with the breath of fire and I usually substitute bridge pose because I'm not that advanced yet. I felt a bit of tension in my neck afterwards but by the next day it was gone. They do suggest modifications for beginners and I would definitely do the modifications if you feel any pain.I admit sometimes I just skip over the mantras at the end although I know they are supposed to be an important part of the practice. Some of them seem so long but maybe I'll get into that more one of these days.

reviewText: So far, this is my favorite Ravi Singh & Ana DVD. First let me describe it in detail as I know that will help you in deciding whether or not to buy it.  It starts with the Tuning in Mantra-Ong Namo GuruDev Namo 3x.  Then there is a breath meditation to use " so that nothing will get on your nerves"  It is 10 sniffs and 1 exhale.  Next are standard kundalini warm-up--spinal grinds and flexes.  Then there are the standing exercises such as stretching back and down, side to side; leg to leg; wide angle stretch; crow squat with breath of fire, etc.  Sitting down stretches are butterfly stretch; one legged stretch with the bent leg in rock pose(if you have bad knees like I do, you will need to put a pillow behind your bent leg OR don't sit in rock pose.  Next is plow pose; cobra pose with wide legs; upward facing bow with breath of fire--this is quite hard as I can not hold upward bow for 2 minutes, which is about how long this exercise is.  Instead I do bridge with a block under my tail bone. The last exercise is Sat Kriya.  My absolute favorite!  Finally there is a relaxation and the Guru Ram Das mantra at the end of class.  Overall I love this DVD.  What I don't like is the music.  The mantra music is by Wah! and is Reggae style.  I don't like Reggae music so at that point in the DVD I turn it off and put on my favorite version of Guru Ram Das.  Ana looks like she wearing her underwear, but since you do kundalini yoga with your eyes closed,I bearly notice her any more.  The DVD is accessible to everyone and I'm glad I got it.  Hope this review helps you.  Oh by the way, all kundalini classes end with the "Long Time Sun" song.  Snatam Kaur recorded a very nice version of this closing song.  Sat Nam
summary: Great workout for day or night
Title: N/A

reviewText: I recieved as a gift a three pack of Ravi and Ana's CD's (Warrior Workout, Navel Power, and Ultimate Stretch). Although I like all of them very much, I tend to reach for the "Ultimate Stretch" DVD more than the others.These workouts put out by Ravi and Ana are very unique.  For one thing, many of the poses are moving, unlike in yoga where most poses are held.  Kundalini also incorporates different kinds of breathing such as the "Breath of Fire" and other kinds of breathing that addresses your state of mind or energy.  I think that Kundalini addresses your Chakras more...as after I do these DVD's I feel this warmth and energy coming from my core.  Maybe this is why these exercises have such an anti-aging effect.The result is a great workout.  After doing this DVD the other day I felt sublime.  I do admit to doing 5 Tibetan exercises prior... but still, even doing this CD alone you feel just wonderful.What is also very special about Ravi and Ana's new DVD's are the mantras that come after the workout.  There is a different mantra on each DVD.  The mantra's are very upbeat, happy and joyful (by Wah!) that you can sing a long with.  The singing feels good.  The mantras have often stayed in my mind all day making feel more uplifted and overall just happier. I look forward to the mantras after each workout. It's a lovely addition to the workout making it truly and overall mind/body/spirit workout.If you are looking for a unique workout that will effect you in ways you may have never experienced before, try these Kundalini  DVD's. They are truly special.
summary: Very Unique and makes you feel very good
